description: Neil Wallis, 64, the former deputy editor of The News of the World, a Rupert Murdoch paper, was acquitted of charges of conspiracy to hack telephones.
title: Ex-Editor Is Acquitted in British Phone Hacking Scandal
title_page: Ex-Editor Is Acquitted in British Phone Hacking Scandal - The New York Times
maintext:
LONDON — The last of the dozens of phone-hacking prosecutions of journalists from The News of the World ended on Wednesday with the acquittal of Neil Wallis, the former deputy editor, on charges of conspiracy to hack telephones between 2003 and 2006.
Mr. Wallis’s editor during those years, Andy Coulson, was jailed last year on hacking-related charges. But Mr. Wallis denied involvement, and a jury at the Old Bailey found him not guilty.
Mr. Wallis, 64, said that case had “ruined my life,” and accused prosecutors of a “vicious, politically driven campaign against the press.”
Outrage over revelations that journalists were illegally gaining access to private voice mail accounts prompted Rupert Murdoch to close down The News of the World in July 2011. In all, eight of the paper’s reporters and a private investigator have been convicted of related charges.
